instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: Lenovo Flex 5 LC56-14T blown after connecting USBc charger - 19V 0.04A
threads.message:
Hi Guys, I know this is an Apple sub, but not sure if you can help me with this one too. I got a schematic and boardview for a close model. location of the parts on the board are a bit shuffled, but schematic ics seem to match. Here link to the Schematic and Boardview -  [URL='https://1drv.ms/f/s!AqUpFIbofx3Hl5wJE05zzzeM_VvZdA?e=bqp3bc']Lenovo FLEX 5-14ALC05 â€“ LC56-14A SVT[/URL]

I got two of these, both have been connected to the same (doggy?) usbc, which blew them one by one. 
I have detected a short on the 5V line and traced it down to <CHIP>U7204</CHIP> (which was glowing at 1V over 5V line). Replaced it, and the short is gone. However, I cannot get 3.3 and 5V lines to fire up.

PU4501 is heating up slightly and was dropping the DCBATOUT voltage from 19 to 9 V. After replacement, it now stays at 19V with no drop.
Now still slight heat signature on PU4501 bench shows 19V/0.04A



[ATTACH type="full" width="1149px"]61161[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full"]61163[/ATTACH]

[ATTACH type="full"]61162[/ATTACH]

PU4501/4551, same voltages
P1 - 4.5V
P2 - 19V
P6 - 0V
P9 - 0V
P11 - 4.7V
P12 - 0V
P13 - 0V
P14 - 0V
P15 - 5V / 2.7V
P17 - 5V

threads.title: Lenovo Flex 5 LC56-14T blown after connecting USBc charger - 19V 0.04A
threads.message:
"P15 - 5V / 2.7V"
5V at pin 15 of PU4501???
Did you solder <CHIP>TPS51393</CHIP> for sure?

2.7V also not good for this pin.
This points to overcurrent on the <SIGNAL>3D3V_AUX_S5</SIGNAL> rail.
Remove <RESISTOR>R2425</RESISTOR> and check if goes up to 3.3V.
If still the same, remove <DIODE>D2502</DIODE> and check again.

Use this schematic.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1SPCqgfN94u9TeP5T3mJp6ZH-uU1EPozH/view?usp=share_link[/URL]

threads.title: Lenovo Flex 5 LC56-14T blown after connecting USBc charger - 19V 0.04A
threads.message:
Yes  <CHIP>TPS51393</CHIP> for sure, but I had one from the donor board, which is the other failed board. So how reliable not sure. And I don't have this chip. 

I would have thought that 5V and 3.,3 fire separately. Could missing both voltages at the same time would be still faulty <CHIP>TPS51395</CHIP>/3

[ATTACH type="full" alt="1684710780702.png"]61164[/ATTACH]

How can you spot which component is it without an accurate boardview? Seems to be a bigger size one? 0603?

Only one in that package size seems to be missing on the left of <DIODE>D2502</DIODE>.
[ATTACH type="full"]61166[/ATTACH]

<SIGNAL>3D3V_RTC_AUX</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>3D3V_AUX</SIGNAL> - 2.7V


Removed the Diode (if that is the one) and I get 2.70 on <SIGNAL>3V3V_AUX_S5</SIGNAL> and lost <SIGNAL>3D3_RTC_AUX</SIGNAL> which was 3.3V with the diode.

threads.title: Lenovo Flex 5 LC56-14T blown after connecting USBc charger - 19V 0.04A
threads.message:
Then the problem doesn't come from RTC area; put back <DIODE>D2502</DIODE>.

<RESISTOR>R2425</RESISTOR> not used probably; free pads next to <DIODE>D2502</DIODE>.

If you change PU4501 and still 2.7V there, then bad KBC.
